Award.AwardTitle: Integrated Career and Educational Pathways in Building Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Lansing Community College and its academic and industry partners propose to create an integrated grades 9-16 academic-career pathways model to give students the technical and workforce skills needed to become leaders in Michigan's growing green building industry. The initiative provides a real life laboratory for students to learn and be ready to enter building science-energy management careers upon graduation. Through linked education-career pathways and the creation of a capstone experience laboratory, this initiative advances knowledge of critical technical and workplace skills for students and faculty. The project will take a system approach towards building science by integrating building science-energy management topics with STEM disciplines. It leverages several resources, including already-developed curricula, standing industry advisory committees, and existing problem- and case-based student projects as the basis for the formal education-career model proposed by the project. The broader impacts of this project include the creation of partnerships among the secondary and post-secondary schools and the building science-energy management industry that can serve as a national model, and the development and implementation of a pathway framework replicable in the other part of the country. Recruitment of minorities as well as the involvement of the National Association of Women in Construction and Hard Hatted Women on the project is expected to broaden participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main purpose of this project is to create a better career pathway for those wishing to become building science professionals. This includes both a focus on creating partnerships with industry and developing a strong snd relevant curriculum. Much of the work can be found at this link: http://www.lcc-dii.org/building-smart/  This is freely distributed as an OER and was demonstrated at the BEST Center at Laney College for all the building science professionals to use in their classroom settings. They have also been presented at various game conferences and building science conferences such as Meaningful Play, Game Developers Conference, GLREA Energy Fair, and the NSF-ATE PI conference. 

These software based learning tools were developed by software development professionals with a part time staff of students in our IT programs. Each simulation is part of the "Smart Neighborhood" series, which is an architecture built to be easy to upgrade and add new modules as we continue to develop the building science program areas. 

http://lcc-dii.org/building-smart/resources.php

The project also included an for-credit course for high school students interested in exploring energy careers, an international conference on high performance buildings, and the construction of a solar powered "smart" tiny house to be used as a lab for students in HVAC, electrical, energy management, home technology integration, and construction.
